p: The 2019–20 coronavirus outbreak is an ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) [1]. The outbreak was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019, declared to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020, and recognized as a pandemic on 11 March 2020 [2], [3]. As of 16 April 2020, more than 2 million cases of COVID-19 have been reported in 213 countries and territories [1]. Liver transplantation (LTX) is the second most common solid organ transplantation worldwide after kidney transplantation. The overall global LTX rate is 3.7 per million population [4], [5]. Indications of LTX also vary according to geography. In developed countries, HCV has been the main indication for LTX, although it is now being replaced by alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic liver disease (NAFLD), and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), while in Asia; hepatitis B and HCC remain a common indication for LTX [6], [7]. In Arab countries, 3,804 liver transplants were performed in the period 1990–2013 in which Living donor liver transplantation (LDLT) represented 80%, and deceased donor liver transplantation (DDLT) represented 20%. Fifty-six percent of the reported cases were in Egypt [8].
